questions.question_text: A Linux administrator needs every new file created on a directory to maintain the group permissions of the same directory. Which of the following commands would satisfy this requirement?

discussion.content:
It sounds like you're describing the setgid bit functionality where when a directory that has it set, will force any new files created within it to have their group set to the same group that's set on the parent directory.

$ sudo mkdir --mode=u+rwx,g+rs,g-w,o-rwx somedir
$ sudo chown saml.apache somedir
$ ll -d somedir/
drwxr-s---. 2 saml apache 4096 Feb 17 20:10 somedir/

Selected Answer: D
D is valid
"chmod g+s <directory>" is equal to "setgid <directory>"
This means that all NEW files (only new files and subdirectories) will have the same group of the directory that contains new files (rather of group of user made the file)
https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/182212/chmod-gs-command

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements BEST represents what the term `agentless` means regarding orchestration?

choices.C: It automatically removes malware from the remote system during orchestration
choices.A: Installation of a tool is not required on the remote system to perform orchestration tasks
choices.D: A tool can only be accessed remotely to perform orchestration tasks
choices.B: It facilitates version control when using infrastructure as code during orchestration

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A: valid answer.
B: wrong because orchestration doesn't concern "version control" (i.g. git )
C: wrong, seems an "antivirus" definition
D: wrong because agentless is not "only accessed remotely"

questions.question_text: Given that a company's policy states that users cannot install third-party tools on Window servers, which of the following protocols will allow a Linux GUI to connect to a Windows server?

discussion.content: The Answer is C. Remote Desktop Protocol. Remmina Remote Desktop Client to connect from Linux to Windows.

comments.content:
I agree with jahute27. This question purposely tried to trick you. The hints are as follows:
-Users cannot install third-party tools on Window servers (You need VNC installed on both sides in order to connect)
-Which of the following protocols (VNC isn't a protocol, it's a third-party tool. RDP [Remote Desktop Protocol] is a protocol, it's in it's name)
I'm also going with C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A: wrong because VNC needs a "VNC client" and a "VNC server" so you need to install third-part tools on Windows server, but is not allowed from given policies.
B: wrong because "NX technology" (commonly known as NX or NoMachine) is a proprietary software application. 
C: valid because RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) can be set in Windows without install any program on windows. You can just install "RDesktop" client on linux.
D: X11 is a desktop server.
VNC is not a protocol, it is a software and 3rd party. In Linux machines xrdp software must be installed. RDP is the answer.
